item.title: These women helped to shape quantum mechanics — it’s time to recognize them
item.author: Indianara Lima Silva
item.content:encoded:
An astute book redresses our collective perception of a field that became known as ‘boys’ physics’.

Indianara Lima Silva

Nature

item.title: Daily briefing: The human cells in our bodies that aren’t genetically ours
item.author: Flora Graham
item.content:encoded:
‘Microchimeric’ cells passed from your mother can challenge basic tenets of immunology. Plus, an experimental cancer vaccine that uses blood ‘cleaned’ with ultraviolet light and the evidence for trying ‘Dry January’.

Flora Graham

Nature

item.title: Self-induced superradiant masing
item.author: Wenzel KerstenNikolaus de ZordoJörg Schmiedmayer
item.content:encoded:
Superradiance is usually driven by light-mediated couplings, leaving the role of direct emitter interactions unclear. Now, it is shown that dipole–dipole interactions in diamond spins drive self-induced pulsed and continuous superradiant masing.

Wenzel KerstenNikolaus de ZordoJörg Schmiedmayer

Nature Physics

item.title: A chiral fermionic valve driven by quantum geometry
item.author: Anvesh DixitPranava K. SivakumarStuart S. P. Parkin
item.content:encoded:
Fermionic currents of opposing chirality can be spatially filtered without the need for a magnetic field using the quantum geometry of topological bands in single-crystal PdGa.

Anvesh DixitPranava K. SivakumarStuart S. P. Parkin

Nature

item.title: Interplay of orbital angular momentum and chirality
item.author: Dongjin OhHendrik BentmannRiccardo Comin
item.content:encoded:
Orbital angular momentum textures can drive orbital currents and enable applications in orbitronics. This Perspective shows how polarization-dependent angle-resolved photoemission spectroscopy can visualize orbital textures in momentum space.

Dongjin OhHendrik BentmannRiccardo Comin

Nature Physics

item.title: AI and quantum science take centre stage under Trump — but with little new proposed funding
item.author: Jenna Ahart
item.content:encoded:
The US administration is banking on public–private partnerships and an expanded workforce to deliver progress, but critics say that this strategy could be offset by other US policies.

Jenna Ahart

Nature

item.title: Electrically controlled nano-OLED metasurfaces
item.author: Jung-El RyuJeehwan Kim
item.content:encoded:
A nanostencil lithography technique enables fabricating arrays of green-emitting OLEDs with pixels as small as 100 nm and an external quantum efficiency of 13.1%.

Jung-El RyuJeehwan Kim

Nature Photonics

item.title: Are we living in a parallel universe? The strange physics of Stranger Things
item.author: Jenna Ahart
item.content:encoded:
Nature speaks to theoretical physicists to explore the real theories that inspired the hit series. Warning: contains spoilers.

Jenna Ahart

Nature

item.title: An 11-qubit atom processor in silicon
item.author: Hermann EdlbauerJunliang WangMichelle Y. Simmons
item.content:encoded:
An 11-qubit atom processor comprising two precision-placed nuclear spin registers of phosphorus in silicon is shown to achieve state-of-the-art Bell-state fidelities of up to 99.5%.

Hermann EdlbauerJunliang WangMichelle Y. Simmons

Nature

item.title: A modular quantum processor made using phosphorus atoms in silicon
item.author: N/A
item.content:encoded:
A high-performance silicon-based quantum processor has been developed in which the spins of nine phosphorus nuclei — divided into two groups, or registers — and two shared electrons act as quantum bits (qubits). The modular design of this 11-qubit processor opens the door to a scalable approach to building large, reliable quantum-computing processors.

Nature

item.title: Programmable 200 GOPS Hopfield-inspired photonic Ising machine
item.author: Nayem Al-KayedCharles St-ArnaultBhavin J. Shastri
item.content:encoded:
An architecture inspired by Hopfield networks based on a programmable, stable, room-temperature optoelectronic oscillator-based photonics Ising machine is introduced that can be used to efficiently address optimization and combinatorics problems.

Nayem Al-KayedCharles St-ArnaultBhavin J. Shastri

Nature

item.title: Visualizing interaction-driven restructuring of quantum Hall edge states
item.author: Jiachen YuHaotan HanAli Yazdani
item.content:encoded:
Scanning tunnelling microscopy is used to image pristine electrostatically defined quantum Hall edge states in graphene with high spatial resolution and demonstrate their interaction-driven restructuring.

Jiachen YuHaotan HanAli Yazdani

Nature

item.title: 3D nanolithography with metalens arrays and spatially adaptive illumination
item.author: Songyun GuChenkai MaoXiaoxing Xia
item.content:encoded:
A three-dimensional (3D) nanofabrication platform based on metalens-generated focal spot arrays is introduced to parallelize two-photon lithography beyond centimetre-scale write field areas, revealing the potential of 3D nanolithography towards wafer-scale production.

Songyun GuChenkai MaoXiaoxing Xia

Nature

item.title: Fusion and fission of particle-like chiral nematic vortex knots
item.author: Darian HallJung-Shen Benny TaiIvan I. Smalyukh
item.content:encoded:
Topologically protected vortex knots are shown to undergo fusion and fission, with electric pulses acting as a switch between the two processes. This might enable applications in electro-optics and photonics.

Darian HallJung-Shen Benny TaiIvan I. Smalyukh

Nature Physics

item.title: Optimal operation of hole spin qubits
item.author: M. BassiE. A. Rodríguez-MenaV. Schmitt
item.content:encoded:
Hole spin semiconductor qubits suffer from charge noise, but now it has been demonstrated that placing them in an appropriately oriented magnetic field can suppress this noise and improve qubit performance.

M. BassiE. A. Rodríguez-MenaV. Schmitt

Nature Physics

item.title: China leads research in 90% of crucial technologies — a dramatic shift this century
item.author: Xiaoying You
item.content:encoded:
The United States tops the remaining areas in an assessment of 74 technologies.

Xiaoying You

Nature

item.title: Quantum computing ‘KPIs’ could distinguish true breakthroughs from spurious claims
item.author: Elizabeth Gibney
item.content:encoded:
Researchers are devising ways to make new machines face off, without the hype.

Elizabeth Gibney

Nature

item.title: A super-conducting diode with ultimate efficiency and noise resilience at 77 K
item.author: N/A
item.content:encoded:
An electrical method is shown to reliably introduce nonreciprocal behaviour across a Josephson junction made of high-temperature cuprate superconductors, which then, under microwave irradiation, forms a ‘quantum superconducting diode’. The device is magnetic-field-free, works at a temperature of 77 K with a diode efficiency of 100%, and, owing to Shapiro steps that quantize the output voltage, has robust noise-filtering.

Nature Physics

item.title: Laser-based conversion electron Mössbauer spectroscopy of 229ThO2
item.author: Ricky ElwellJames E. S. TerhuneEric R. Hudson
item.content:encoded:
Laser-induced conversion electron Mössbauer spectroscopy, which detects electrons emitted by 229Th nuclei in a thin ThO2 sample excited by vacuum ultraviolet light, is demonstrated, opening the possibility of a conversion-electron-based nuclear clock.

Ricky ElwellJames E. S. TerhuneEric R. Hudson

Nature

item.title: Observation of deuteron and antideuteron formation from resonance-decay nucleons
item.author: S. AcharyaA. AgarwalN. Zurlo
item.content:encoded:
The ALICE Collaboration provides details on the microscopic mechanism that ends up creating antideuteron in high-energy proton–proton collisions at the Large Hadron Collider.

S. AcharyaA. AgarwalN. Zurlo

Nature

item.title: Electrically tuned light topology
item.author: Shai TsessesAviv Karnieli
item.content:encoded:
Controlling topological photonic quasiparticles is a prerequisite for their implementation in devices. Now, their precise manipulation has been demonstrated using synthetic gauge fields based on the manipulation of the material’s dielectric index.

Shai TsessesAviv Karnieli

Nature Physics

item.title: Quarks in ‘exotic’ quartets prefer to stick together
item.author: Elena Santopinto
item.content:encoded:
Evidence of a particle made up of four tightly bound quarks tests physicists’ understanding of the force that holds protons and neutrons together.

Elena Santopinto

Nature

item.title: Determination of the spin and parity of all-charm tetraquarks
item.author: A. HayrapetyanV. MakarenkoA. Snigirev
item.content:encoded:
The CMS Collaboration reports the measurement of the spin, parity, and charge conjugation properties of all-charm tetraquarks, exotic fleeting particles formed in proton–proton collisions at the Large Hadron Collider.

A. HayrapetyanV. MakarenkoA. Snigirev

Nature

item.title: An optical conveyor belt for 3,000 qubits
item.author: Giampaolo Pitruzzello
item.content:encoded:
Giampaolo Pitruzzello

Nature Photonics

item.title: Quantum superconducting diode effect with perfect efficiency above liquid-nitrogen temperature
item.author: Heng WangYuying ZhuDing Zhang
item.content:encoded:
A device for rectifying supercurrents at liquid-nitrogen temperature with high efficiency is demonstrated. This is a practical step towards implementing dissipationless electronics.

Heng WangYuying ZhuDing Zhang

Nature Physics

item.title: Twisting the Hubbard model into the momentum-mixing Hatsugai–Kohmoto model
item.author: Peizhi MaiJinchao ZhaoPhilip W. Phillips
item.content:encoded:
The Hubbard model describes the physics of strongly correlated electron systems, but is difficult to solve. Now, a scheme to systematically and efficiently relate the exactly solvable Hatsugai–Kohmoto model to the Hubbard model has been identified.

Peizhi MaiJinchao ZhaoPhilip W. Phillips

Nature Physics

item.title: Fault-tolerant quantum computation with polylogarithmic time and constant space overheads
item.author: Shiro TamiyaMasato KoashiHayata Yamasaki
item.content:encoded:
Quantum low-density parity-check codes are anticipated to be an efficient approach to quantum error correction. Now it has been proven that these codes can be time-efficient with only a constant overhead in the required number of qubits.

Shiro TamiyaMasato KoashiHayata Yamasaki

Nature Physics

item.title: A large-scale reconfigurable multiplexed quantum photonic network
item.author: Natalia Herrera ValenciaAnnameng MaMehul Malik
item.content:encoded:
A reconfigurable eight-user photonic network is realized by connecting two local four-user networks through a programmable 8 × 8-dimensional multi-port device. Multiplexed routing and swapping of qubit entanglement are demonstrated for all network configurations and channels.

Natalia Herrera ValenciaAnnameng MaMehul Malik

Nature Photonics

item.title: Learning quantum states of continuous-variable systems
item.author: Francesco A. MeleAntonio A. MeleSalvatore F. E. Oliviero
item.content:encoded:
Finding a classical description of a quantum state can require resource-intensive tomography protocols. It has now been shown that, for bosonic systems, tomography is extremely inefficient in general, but can be done efficiently for some useful states.

Francesco A. MeleAntonio A. MeleSalvatore F. E. Oliviero

Nature Physics

item.title: Entanglement-enhanced nanoscale single-spin sensing
item.author: Xu ZhouMengqi WangJiangfeng Du
item.content:encoded:
An entanglement-enhanced sensing strategy making use of entangled nitrogen–vacancy pairs is described, demonstrating a 3.4-fold improvement in sensitivity and a 1.6-fold improvement in spatial resolution relative to single nitrogen–vacancy centres under ambient conditions.

Xu ZhouMengqi WangJiangfeng Du

Nature

item.title: Operating two exchange-only qubits in parallel
item.author: Mateusz T. MądzikFlorian LuthiJames S. Clarke
item.content:encoded:
Parallel operation of two exchange-only qubits consisting of six quantum dots arranged linearly is shown to be achievable and maintains qubit control quality compared with sequential operation, with potential for use in scaled quantum computing.

Mateusz T. MądzikFlorian LuthiJames S. Clarke

Nature

item.title: Multi-qubit nanoscale sensing with entanglement as a resource
item.author: Jared RovnyShimon KolkowitzNathalie P. de Leon
item.content:encoded:
Controlling pairs of nitrogen vacancy centres enables the measurement of magnetic correlations below the optical diffraction limit, and the use of entangled pairs shows a linear scaling of the measurement sensitivity with readout noise, as opposed to the quadratic scaling that would be obtained with unentangled spins.

Jared RovnyShimon KolkowitzNathalie P. de Leon

Nature

item.title: Trump’s AI ‘Genesis Mission’: what are the risks and opportunities?
item.author: Elizabeth GibneyAlexandra WitzeJenna Ahart
item.content:encoded:
National laboratories have been instructed to broaden access to their data sets to accelerate research as part of the federal government’s AI platform. But who stands to benefit?

Elizabeth GibneyAlexandra WitzeJenna Ahart

Nature

item.title: Electrical control of photon spin angular momentum in organic electroluminescent materials
item.author: Francesco FurlanMichal ŠámalMatthew J. Fuchter
item.content:encoded:
Electrical tuning of the recombination zone in circularly polarized (CP) OLEDs enables switching the CP generation mechanism between normal and anomalous CP electroluminescence. This is exploited to electrically control the handedness of emitted CP light from the same device with the same enantiomer material.

Francesco FurlanMichal ŠámalMatthew J. Fuchter

Nature Photonics

item.title: Why the world must wake up to China’s science leadership
item.author: Kerry Brown
item.content:encoded:
The nation’s next generation of scientists and technologists will shape the coming decades.

Kerry Brown

Nature

item.title: Thirty years of Bose–Einstein condensation
item.author: Zoran HadzibabicUlrich Schneider
item.content:encoded:
In 1995, two papers reported long-sought proof of an exotic state of matter — with applications in fields as diverse as quantum computing and cosmology.

Zoran HadzibabicUlrich Schneider

Nature

item.title: Electric toroidal invariance generates distinct transverse electromagnetic responses
item.author: Kai DuDaegeun JoSang-Wook Cheong
item.content:encoded:
Magnetic toroidal invariance generates transverse electromagnetic effects in materials with broken symmetries. Now a distinct magnetic response is shown to emerge in ferro-rotational systems in which both inversion and time-reversal symmetries are preserved.

Kai DuDaegeun JoSang-Wook Cheong

Nature Physics

item.title: Progress in quantum structured light
item.author: Andrew ForbesFazilah NothlawalaAdam Vallés
item.content:encoded:
This Review provides an overview of the progress in quantum structured light, both as single and entangled photon states, with an emphasis on prospective applications in quantum information science such as quantum communication and quantum imaging.

Andrew ForbesFazilah NothlawalaAdam Vallés

Nature Photonics

item.title: Topological nodal i-wave superconductivity in PtBi2
item.author: Susmita ChangdarOleksandr SuvorovJeroen van den Brink
item.content:encoded:
Angle-resolved photoemission spectroscopy shows that Weyl semimetal PtBi2 harbours nodes in its superconducting gap, implying unconventional i-wave pairing symmetry.

Susmita ChangdarOleksandr SuvorovJeroen van den Brink

Nature

item.title: A charge transfer mechanism for optically addressable solid-state spin pairs
item.author: Islay O. RobertsonBenjamin WhitefieldJean-Philippe Tetienne
item.content:encoded:
Optical spin defects in semiconductors are crucial for applications, but it is often difficult to establish their microscopic origin. A mechanism for the spin behaviour of a family of bright emitters in hexagonal boron nitride has now been identified.

Islay O. RobertsonBenjamin WhitefieldJean-Philippe Tetienne

Nature Physics

item.title: Budget release: Canada courts US researchers and signals wider commitment to science
item.author: Brian Owens
item.content:encoded:
Artificial intelligence and international scientists are some of the big winners in the country’s spending plan this year.

Brian Owens

Nature

item.title: Standing up for Inuit-led research in Canada’s changing Arctic
item.author: Chris Woolston
item.content:encoded:
In Canada’s far north, sociologist Jessica Penney is mixing research with advocacy.

Chris Woolston

Nature

item.title: Science on shaky ground: Canadian research shifts in the wake of US cuts
item.author: Lesley Evans Ogden
item.content:encoded:
Scientists hunt for the silver lining amid the changing funding landscape.

Lesley Evans Ogden

Nature

item.title: Electro-generated excitons for tunable lanthanide electroluminescence
item.author: Jing TanPeng ZhangXiaogang Liu
item.content:encoded:
The electroluminescence emitted from lanthanide fluoride nanocrystals functionalized with ligands is shown to be tunable, providing a method for exciton control in insulating nanocrystal systems and offering a pathway for spectrally precise electroluminescent materials.

Jing TanPeng ZhangXiaogang Liu

Nature

item.title: A cornerstone of entanglement theory restored
item.author: Matthias Christandl
item.content:encoded:
The second law of thermodynamics says that entropy may only ever increase during the conversion of one physical state into another. Finding an analogous quantity to characterize the conversion of entangled quantum states has been a rollercoaster ride.

Matthias Christandl

Nature Physics

item.title: Self-compressed waveform-stable light transients enabling water-window attosecond spectroscopy
item.author: Valentina Utrio LanfaloniFederico VismarraHans Jakob Wörner
item.content:encoded:
Researchers demonstrate phase-stable sub-cycle self-compressed light transients, as well as their sampling down to half of an optical cycle, and determine their waveform phase offset. They apply the transients to soft X-ray high-harmonic generation and attosecond X-ray absorption spectroscopy.

Valentina Utrio LanfaloniFederico VismarraHans Jakob Wörner

Nature Photonics

item.title: Material system enhances superconducting qubits
item.author: N/A
item.content:encoded:
In the development of large-scale quantum processors, material improvements yield rapid progress because they can be readily translated to many devices and platforms. This work shows that, if they are built from tantalum and silicon, superconducting qubits can have millisecond-scale lifetimes and coherence times and reduced fabrication-related contamination.

Nature

item.title: Attosecond physics in optical near fields
item.author: Jonas HeimerlStefan MeierPeter Hommelhoff
item.content:encoded:
Attosecond control of electrons in nanostructures requires resolving dynamics in the optical near field. Now, an experiment finds low-energy spectral stripes that track subcycle electron emission and allow the isolation of attosecond electron bursts.

Jonas HeimerlStefan MeierPeter Hommelhoff

Nature Physics

item.title: iPEX enables micrometre-resolution deep spatial proteomics via tissue expansion
item.author: Fengxiang WangCuiji SunYilong Zou
item.content:encoded:
Isotropic tissue magnification is integrated with matrix-assisted laser desorption/ionization mass spectrometry imaging to enable untargeted spatial proteomics at micrometre resolution and with high protein identification rates in multiple tissue types.

Fengxiang WangCuiji SunYilong Zou

Nature

item.title: Photoinduced twist and untwist of moiré superlattices
item.author: Cameron J. R. DuncanAmalya C. JohnsonFang Liu
item.content:encoded:
Femtosecond photoexcitation drives a coherent twist–untwist motion of the moiré superlattice in 2° and 57° twisted WSe2/MoSe2 heterobilayers.

Cameron J. R. DuncanAmalya C. JohnsonFang Liu

Nature
